ã¤ããæ ªå¼ä¼ç¤¾ |company_logo = |company_type = [[Public company|Public]]
| traded_as = {{tyo|7951}} |foundation = October 12, 1887|area_served = |location_city = [[Hamamatsu]], [[Shizuoka prefecture]] |location_country = [[Japan]] |key_people = [[Torakusu Yamaha]], founder |industry = [[Conglomerate (company)|Conglomerate]] |products = Musical instruments, Audio/Video, Electronics, Computer related products, [[automobile]]s, Vehicle Engines, [[Personal water craft]], golf clubs |revenue = {{profit}} 4.676 billion US$ (March 31, 2009) |operating_income = 140.95 million US$ (March 31, 2009) |net_income = {{loss}}(209.87) million US$ (March 31, 2009) |num_employees = 26,803 (March 31, 2009) |parent = |subsid = |homepage = [http://www.yamaha.com Yamaha.com] |footnotes = }} The '''Yamaha RGX''' and '''RGZ''' [[electric guitar]]s Series are manufactured by the [[Yamaha Corporation]] and bear a close resemblance to the [[Ibanez RG]] series, the [[Jackson Soloist]] and other "superstrat" enhanced copies of the [[Fender Stratocaster]]. These Taiwan-made instruments were introduced in 1987. RGX Series guitars often have 24 or more frets and a [[bolt-on neck]]. Some high-end models use a neck-through-body design. Some come with Yamaha active [[Pick up (music technology)|pickups]], two single coils and one humbucker. Most of these instruments were generally known as RGZ, including the RGZ820R, a custom plaid graphic model with two [[humbucker]]s and a Floyd Rose licensed locking tremolo, played by rock guitarist [[Blues Saraceno]]. The RGX guitars were upgraded in 2003 with a 3D headstock sporting a 3+3 tuner layout and a piezo bridge option for acoustic-like tones. Famous endorsees of the RGX/RGZ guitars included Blues Saraceno and [[Ty Tabor]] of [[King's X]], who got his namesake RGX-TT and RGX-TTD6 signature models in 2000. ==See also== * [[Yamaha electric guitar models]] * [[Superstrat]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Yamaha electric guitars series}} [[Category:Yamaha electric guitars|RGX|RGZ|SG]]
